verse_commentaries.commentary: The opening declaration 'בַּֽיהֹוָ֨ה ׀ חָסִ֗יתִי' (in YHWH I take refuge) uses the divine name emphatically at the beginning, creating strong positional emphasis. The quotation that follows 'אֵ֭יךְ תֹּאמְר֣וּ לְנַפְשִׁ֑י' (how can you say to my soul) is puzzling—who is speaking to whom? The textual variant (נודו/נוּדִי) creates ambiguity: ketiv has plural imperative, qere has feminine singular. The simile 'flee like a bird to your mountain' is vivid but raises questions about whether 'your mountain' is singular or plural in intent.
figurative_analysis: bird fleeing to mountain - vulnerable creature seeking refuge
soul as addressee (if נַפְשִׁי is vocative)
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Sets up the dialogical tension central to thesis—competing counsel between flee vs. trust.

verse_commentaries.commentary: Highly detailed archery imagery with three sequential verbs: 'יִדְרְכ֬וּן' (they bend), 'כּוֹנְנ֣וּ' (they set/establish), 'לִיר֥וֹת' (to shoot). The phrase 'בְּמוֹ־אֹ֝֗פֶל' (in darkness/in gloom) is curious—the prefix בְּמוֹ is unusual. Target is 'לְיִשְׁרֵי־לֵֽב' (to the upright of heart)—why 'upright of heart' rather than just 'upright'? The present tense description creates immediacy and threat.
figurative_analysis: darkness as both literal (stealth) and moral (evil operates hidden)
heart as seat of moral character
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes the 'earthly threat' that makes flight seem reasonable, but darkness contrasts with God's omniscient vision in v.4.

verse_commentaries.commentary: The crux of the psalm: 'כִּ֣י הַ֭שָּׁתוֹת יֵהָרֵס֑וּן' (when the foundations are destroyed). What are 'הַ֭שָּׁתוֹת'? This rare word (from שׁית, 'to set/place') could be architectural, cosmic, or metaphorical. The rhetorical question 'צַ֝דִּ֗יק מַה־פָּעָֽל' (the righteous, what has he done/what can he do?) is grammatically ambiguous—perfect tense פָּעָֽל could be past action ('what has he done [to deserve this]?') or potential ('what can he do?'). This verse is syntactically the end of the quoted counsel but thematically the pivot point.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: The unanswered question is central to thesis—psalm doesn't answer what righteous DO but shifts to what God IS DOING.

verse_commentaries.commentary: The turning point: double location formula 'יְהֹוָ֤ה ׀ בְּֽהֵ֘יכַ֤ל קׇדְשׁ֗וֹ יְהֹוָה֮ בַּשָּׁמַ֢יִם כִּ֫סְא֥וֹ' (YHWH in his holy temple/YHWH in heaven his throne). The parallelism suggests either simultaneity (both places at once) or identification (heavenly temple). Powerful body-part parallelism: 'עֵינָ֥יו יֶחֱז֑וּ עַפְעַפָּ֥יו יִ֝בְחֲנ֗וּ' (his eyes behold/his eyelids test). Why 'eyelids' (עַפְעַפָּיו)? This is anthropomorphic and oddly specific. The verb יִבְחֲנ֗וּ (test/examine) suggests metallurgical refining—active scrutiny, not passive observation.
figurative_analysis: eyelids as intensification of seeing—careful, deliberate gaze
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: The spatial shift (earth→heaven) is exactly what thesis describes as rhetorical pivot. Vision motif begins God's comprehensive sight.

verse_commentaries.commentary: Antithetical structure: 'יְהֹוָה֮ צַדִּ֢יק יִ֫בְחָ֥ן וְ֭רָשָׁע' (YHWH tests the righteous and the wicked). But there's syntactic ambiguity—does YHWH test both, or does he test the righteous BUT (his soul) hates the wicked? The phrase 'שָֽׂנְאָ֥ה נַפְשֽׁוֹ' (his soul hates) is striking anthropomorphism—God's 'nephesh' (soul/inner being) hates. The object of hatred is compound: 'וְאֹהֵ֣ב חָמָ֑ס' (and lover of violence/injustice). Why 'lover of violence' rather than just 'violent one'?
figurative_analysis: soul/nephesh as seat of divine emotion
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine discrimination between righteous/wicked fits thesis's examination theme. But puzzle: if God tests righteous, is this positive or negative?

verse_commentaries.commentary: Explosive judgment imagery: 'יַמְטֵ֥ר עַל־רְשָׁעִ֗ים פַּ֫חִ֥ים אֵ֣שׁ וְ֭גׇפְרִית' (he will rain upon wicked snares, fire and sulfur). The verb יַמְטֵר (rain) inverts blessing—rain normally life-giving, here death-dealing. Multiple judgment elements: פַּחִים (snares/traps), אֵשׁ (fire), גׇפְרִית (sulfur—Sodom and Gomorrah echo), וְרוּחַ זִלְעָפוֹת (and wind of scorching/storms). Final phrase 'מְנָ֣ת כּוֹסָֽם' (portion of their cup)—cup as inheritance metaphor. The accumulation creates overwhelming sense of comprehensive judgment.
figurative_analysis: fire and sulfur as Sodom allusion
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine judgment answers the counsel of despair—wicked won't triumph. But violence of imagery is striking and worth exploring.

verse_commentaries.commentary: Tripartite conclusion: (1) 'כִּֽי־צַדִּיק יְ֭הֹוָה' (for righteous [is] YHWH)—divine character; (2) 'צְדָק֣וֹת אָהֵ֑ב' (righteousness/righteous-deeds he loves)—divine preference; (3) 'יָ֝שָׁ֗ר יֶחֱז֥וּ פָנֵֽימוֹ' (upright shall behold his face)—eschatological promise. The word צְדָקוֹת is plural—'righteous deeds' or abstract 'righteousnesses'? The verb יֶחֱזוּ (shall behold) recalls v.4's יֶחֱזוּ (his eyes behold)—divine seeing now reciprocated by human seeing. But 'behold his face' (פָנֵֽימוֹ) is theologically loaded given Exod 33:20 'no one can see my face and live.'
figurative_analysis: face of God as ultimate blessing/intimacy
righteousness as both divine attribute and divine love-object
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Beatific vision concludes the psalm's vision motif—perfect fit with thesis. But tension with Exodus prohibition needs exploration.

thematic_threads: Dialogical structure (vv.1b-3 quoted counsel, vv.4-7 implicit response) creates dramatic tension without explicit rebuttal markers
Vision/sight motif progression: wicked shoot in darkness (v.2) → God's eyes/eyelids examine (v.4) → upright behold God's face (v.7)
Spatial axis: horizontal flight to mountains (v.1) vs. vertical throne in heaven (v.4)—epistemological shift
YHWH name appears 5x with concentration in vv.4-5 (4 occurrences), emphasizing divine agency at turning point
Body-part anthropomorphisms: eyes, eyelids (v.4), soul/nephesh (v.5), face (v.7)—embodied divine presence
Righteousness vocabulary density: צדיק (vv.3,5), צַדִּיק (v.7a), צְדָקוֹת (v.7b), יָשָׁר (vv.2,7)—moral framework
Testing/examination language: יֶחֱזוּ, יִבְחֲנוּ (v.4), יִבְחָן (v.5)—discriminating divine judgment
Unanswered rhetorical question (v.3) structurally central but left hanging—answered by reframing, not direct response
interesting_questions: What accounts for the ketiv/qere variant נודו/נוּדִי in v.1, and does the feminine singular imperative suggest נֶפֶשׁ (soul) as grammatical addressee?
What exactly are 'the foundations' (הַשָּׁתוֹת) in v.3—architectural, cosmic, social, or moral—and how does this rare term function elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible?
Why does v.4 use the specific body-part 'eyelids' (עַפְעַפָּיו) rather than just 'eyes'—what does this unusual anthropomorphism contribute?
How should we understand God's 'testing' (בחן) of the righteous in v.5—is this positive (refining), neutral (examination), or threatening (trial)?
What is the function of the unusual prefix בְּמוֹ in 'בְּמוֹ־אֹפֶל' (v.2), and how does it differ from simple בְּ?
Why does v.6 combine hunting imagery (snares/פַּחִים) with theophanic judgment imagery (fire, sulfur, scorching wind)?
How does the psalm's promise that 'the upright shall behold His face' (v.7) relate to the prohibition in Exod 33:20 that no one can see God's face and live?
Is the plural צְדָקוֹת in v.7 abstract intensity ('righteousness') or concrete plurality ('righteous deeds'), and what theological difference does this make?
Why does the psalm leave the central rhetorical question of v.3 ('what can the righteous do?') syntactically unanswered?
What is the relationship between the 'holy temple' and 'throne in heaven' in v.4—simultaneity, identification, or poetic parallelism?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Focus on הַשָּׁתוֹת (foundations), עַפְעַפָּיים (eyelids), בחן (test/examine), פָנִים (face) in theophany contexts
CONCORDANCE: Track 'behold face' language across Psalms and Torah; refuge (חסה) formula; testing vocabulary
TEXTUAL: Investigate ketiv/qere variant in v.1 and LXX divergences (especially v.4's 'poor' addition)
FIGURATIVE: Cup/portion metaphor (v.6), darkness/light opposition, rain as judgment inversion
COMMENTARY: Verses requiring interpretive decisions: v.3 (foundations), v.4 (temple/heaven relation), v.7 (seeing God's face)
